a poem that has 39 lines and a complicated pattern of repeating lines: I taught myself to write haikus, sonnets, and sestinas.
More examplesFewer examplesYou can write a sestina on any subject you choose.A sestina is an ideal form to use if you want to write about a situation where you are trapped or helpless or lost.The sestina has six stanzas, each comprising six unrhymed lines, in which the words at the end of the first stanza’s lines reappear in a rolling pattern in the other stanzas.
